news_article: Nearly 30 lakh people were put under lockdown in China on Monday after a surge in coronavirus cases linked to a travelling salesman in the country's two cities in northeastern Jilin province. The country reported 109 COVID-19 new cases. Around 2 crore people across China's northeast are now barred from leaving their homes, according to reports.

news_headline: Mink mass graves in Denmark might contaminate groundwater: Study
news_article: A study commissioned by Denmark's Environmental Protection Agency states that decomposing mink buried in dirt pits following a nationwide cull might contaminate groundwater. Danish government ordered a cull of some 1.7 crore mink in November after hundreds of farms suffered outbreaks of coronavirus. Authorities buried some of the mink in pits in a military area under two metres of soil.

news_headline: Iran seizes S Korean-flagged tanker amid tensions over frozen assets
news_article: Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) on Monday said that it has seized a South Korean-flagged tanker for polluting the Gulf with chemicals. The ship is carrying 7,200 tonnes of ethanol, a semi-official news agency said. This comes amid tensions between Iran and South Korea over Iranian funds frozen at South Korean banks due to US sanctions.

news_headline: UK COVID-19 variant detected in 41 countries/territories: WHO
news_article: World Health Organization has said that the new coronavirus variant that emerged in the UK has been detected in 41 countries/territories so far. UK identified the new COVID-19 variant that it said is 70% more transmissible on December 14 last year. Several countries have suspended travel from Britain in a bid to contain the spread of the new strain.

news_headline: Oman Sultan's eldest son to succeed him under new law
news_article: Oman's Sultan Haitham will be succeeded by his eldest son Dhi Yazan, according to a new basic law published on Tuesday. The law also creates a new position of crown prince and establishes succession from ruler to the eldest son. Haitham had announced plans for the constitutional change on Monday, a year after the death of his predecessor Sultan Qaboos.

news_headline: Aus names over 100 venues in Sydney as potential COVID-19 hotspots
news_article: Australian officials in New South Wales have named over 100 venues across Sydney as potential COVID-19 hotspots. The officials have also instructed thousands of people who visited these venues to self-isolate and also get themselves tested. Last week, all Australian states and territories had imposed travel restrictions on Sydney residents over the recent COVID-19 outbreak in the city.

news_headline: Man's lie caused South Australia lockdown where 1 per family can go out
news_article: South Australia's lockdown where only one person from a household is allowed to leave home was caused by a man's lie to contact tracers. The man said he was a customer at a pizza shop when in fact he worked several shifts there with another COVID-19-infected worker. Authorities assumed he caught a highly contagious strain during a very short exposure.

news_headline: Trump's fraud allegations 'farcical': Ex-head of election security
news_article: Calling US President Donald Trump's fraud allegations "farcical", former head of US election security Chris Krebs said that allegations of voting machines being manipulated by foreign countries were baseless. Americans should have 100% confidence in their vote, Krebs added. Krebs was fired by Trump for saying that the November 3 election was the most secure in American history.

news_headline: World's largest glove maker does mass screening as staff test COVID-19 +ve
news_article: Top Glove, the world's largest manufacturer of rubber gloves, is conducting a mass screening of its workers after some of them at its Malaysian factories tested COVID-19 positive. Affected employees are currently under quarantine while contract tracing and testing are being done at two facilities. Top Glove's 28 factories were temporarily shut in 2020 after over 4,000 workers contracted COVID-19.

news_headline: Trump orders assessment of security risks of Chinese drones in US fleet
news_article: President Donald Trump on Monday signed an executive order directing US agencies to assess any security risks from Chinese-made drones in American government fleets. If warranted, the use of drones should be discontinued and their removal should be prioritised, the order said. Trump also ordered an assessment of drones built by countries deemed as foreign adversaries, including Russia and Iran.

news_headline: Understand shock but violence not justified: Macron on Prophet Mohammed cartoons
news_article: French President Emmanuel Macron has said he can understand people could be shocked by Prophet Mohammed's caricatures, but he'll "never accept that violence can be justified". This comes after three people were killed at a church in Nice in an attack that Macron termed as "Islamist terror". Earlier, a teacher was beheaded after showing Prophet Mohammed's cartoons in a class.

news_headline: Hungary becomes 1st EU nation to approve Russia's Sputnik V vaccine
news_article: Hungary on Wednesday became the first EU nation to approve Russia's Sputnik V COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use. Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto, who's due to visit Moscow on Friday, said the government had received a draft contract to buy the vaccine from Russia's RDIF sovereign wealth fund. Hungary has vaccinated only a little over 1% of its population so far.

news_headline: US offers ₹36.7 cr for info on China's violation of N Korea sanctions
news_article: The US has accused China of "flagrant violation" of its obligation to enforce international sanctions on North Korea and offered rewards of up to ₹36.7 crore for information about sanctions evasions. The US said that it has observed ships carrying sanctioned goods from North Korea to China on 555 separate occasions over the past year.

news_headline: Video shows the moment a building collapsed in Turkey during earthquake
news_article: Witnesses have captured the moment a building fell in İzmir during a magnitude 7.0 earthquake in Turkey's Aegean region on Friday. The nation's disaster agency said the quake occurred at 2.51pm at a depth of 10 miles. "Our state has taken action with all its institutions starting from the moment of the earthquake to help those affected," Turkish President said.

news_headline: 1,500 nurses die due to COVID-19, same as nurse death toll during WWI: ICN
news_article: At least 1,500 nurses have died from coronavirus, the same as the number of nurses who died during World War I, the International Council of Nurses said. The figure includes nurses from 44 countries and is known to be an underestimate of true death toll, ICN said. Its own analysis suggests about 10% of cases globally are among healthcare workers.

news_headline: What is the Candida auris outbreak that was reported in a COVID-19 unit in US?
news_article: Candida auris is an emerging fungus that is often multidrug-resistant and some strains are resistant to all three available classes of antifungals, according to US' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The CDC said it is difficult to identify with standard laboratory methods. A Candida auris outbreak was reported in a COVID-19 unit in Florida last year.

news_headline: UK Police discover 1st cannabis farm in London's financial district
news_article: The UK Police on Wednesday said that they have found the first cannabis farm in London's financial district, Square Mile, and arrested two people in connection with it. There were reports of a "strong smell of cannabis", which led to the raid, they added. The police also said that 826 plants were dismantled and destroyed by police officers.

news_headline: Vote recount fight about ensuring US has faith in elections: Trump
news_article: US President Donald Trump said that his fight for recounting of votes is to ensure that "Americans can have faith in this election, and in all future elections". Trump alleged that the "corrupt mail-in balloting scheme that Democrats systematically put into place" allowed votes to be altered. Several election officials have said there was no evidence of massive voters fraud.

news_headline: Biden names Indian-American Vanita Gupta as associate attorney general
news_article: US President-elect Joe Biden on Thursday nominated Indian-American Vanita Gupta to serve as the associate attorney general while announcing key appointments to the Department of Justice. Gupta would be the first woman of colour to serve in this role. Biden nominated Merrick Garland for attorney general and Lisa Monaco for deputy attorney general.

news_headline: Gold, silver jewellery washes up on beach in Venezuela; pics surface
news_article: Gold and silver jewellery, ornaments, and golden nuggets have washed up on a beach in Venezuela's Guaca. Dozens of villagers said they had found at least one precious object, with unconfirmed reports that some had sold their discoveries for as much as $1,500. "I began to shake...It was the first time something special has happened to me," a fisherman said.

news_headline: AK-47 manufacturer tests its new guided anti-aircraft missile, releases video
news_article: Kalashnikov, the maker of AK-47 assault rifles, has released a video as it successfully carried out a test of its new Strela-guided anti-aircraft missile. The test was carried out at the Donguz range in Russia's Orenburg Region on the border with Kazakhstan. The Strela-9M333 guided missile is capable of shooting down low-flying planes, helicopters, drones and cruise missiles.

news_headline: Japan finds COVID-19 variant in three people with no record of travel to UK
news_article: Japanese doctors have detected a fast-spreading variant of the new coronavirus, first discovered in Britain, in three people who had not travelled there. The three infected people, aged from their 20s to their 60s, first had symptoms in early January, Japan's Health Ministry said. An official said that the authorities are looking into how the three became infected.

news_headline: Builder fined record ₹5.8 crore for destroying bat roost in London
news_article: A building firm that carried out demolition work at a site known to be inhabited by bats has been handed a £600,000 (₹5.8 crore) fine, the largest ever issued by a court for a wildlife crime, according to police. Bellway admitted destroying a breeding site in south-east London, in 2018, where soprano pipistrelle bats had been documented the previous year.

news_headline: South Africa identifies new coronavirus strain driving second wave of cases
news_article: South Africa has identified a new variant of the coronavirus that is driving the second wave of infections, Health Minister Zweli Mkhize said. This comes days after the UK said it had also found a new variant of the virus boosting cases. The WHO said it was in touch with the South African researchers who identified the new variant.

news_headline: US records world's biggest single-day COVID-19 spike as 1L test +ve
news_article: United States on Friday recorded 1,00,233 coronavirus cases, marking the biggest one-day jump recorded by any country since the beginning of the pandemic, according to a Reuters tally. US' daily rise exceeded the 97,894 cases reported by India on a single day in September. The US is the worst-hit country in the world with over 90 lakh COVID-19 cases.

news_headline: 20 kids in Spain sprout hair like werewolves on taking wrong medicine, pics surface
news_article: Twenty children in Spain sprouted hair all over their bodies like werewolves after they were mistakenly given hair restorer instead of medicine for stomach upsets. The mix-up happened after mislabeled syrups were delivered to pharmacies, where chemists used it to treat reflux. Pictures showing the hair-covered skin of the young children have now gone viral on social media.

news_headline: Ball in US' court: Iran President Rouhani on nuclear dispute
news_article: Iran President Hassan Rouhani urged US President-elect Joe Biden to rejoin the nuclear deal, saying that "the ball is in the US court now". "If Washington returns to Iran's 2015 nuclear deal, we'll also fully respect our commitments under the pact," he added. Rouhani further said, "Trump's political career is over...and his 'maximum pressure' policy on Iran has completely failed."

news_headline: Tyrant's era has come to an end: Iran Prez on Trump's departure
news_article: Commenting on US President Donald Trump's departure from the White House, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said that "a tyrant's era came to an end". Trump's four years "bore no fruit other than injustice and corruption and causing problems for his own people and the world", Rouhani added. During his presidency, Trump withdrew US from Iran's nuclear deal and reimposed sanctions.

news_headline: Saudi Arabia becomes 2nd Gulf country to approve Pfizer's vaccine
news_article: After Bahrain, Saudi Arabia has become the second Gulf country to approve the use of COVID-19 vaccine developed by Pfizer and German partner BioNTech, the state media reported on Thursday. The Saudi Food and Drug Authority said it would analyse each vaccine shipment to ensure quality standards before using it. The country has reported over 3.5 lakh COVID-19 cases.

news_headline: 12 of 22 miners trapped underground for a week alive in China, send note
news_article: Rescuers have said that 12 miners trapped underground after an explosion in a Chinese gold mine a week ago are still alive. The workers managed to send a note to rescuers, state media reported. Twenty-two miners were trapped at the Hushan mine near Yantai on January 10 after the explosion that damaged the communications system of the mine.

news_headline: Unfair vaccine distribution risks 'catastrophic moral failure': WHO
news_article: The WHO's Director-General Tedros Adhanom on Monday spoke up on unfair COVID-19 vaccine distribution and said, "I need to be blunt...The world is on the brink of a catastrophic moral failure." He said, "Some countries and companies continue to prioritise bilateral deals." He also said that "Me first" approach leaves the world's poorest and most vulnerable people at risk.

news_headline: Dubai Crown Prince 'races' against ostriches on his cycle, shares video
news_article: Dubai Crown Prince Sheikh Hamdan bin Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum shared a video on Instagram in which he is seen 'racing' against two ostriches on his cycle. A speeding ostrich overtakes Hamdan, crosses his path and moves to the other side of the road. "This morning another close call #2021," he wrote while sharing the video.

news_headline: Women post pics of legs in stockings to support jailed ex-Miss Belarus
news_article: Women are posting photos of their legs in stockings to support former Miss Belarus Olga Khizhinkova who was jailed for protesting against the re-election of Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko. Several women posted photos of their legs beside packets of the stockings modelled by Khizhinkova, many tying the red and white protest flag, used by the opposition, around their thighs.

news_headline: 7 Pak COVID-19 patients die after hospital runs out of oxygen supply
news_article: Seven coronavirus patients at the Khyber Teaching Hospital in Peshawar, Pakistan died after oxygen supply at the hospital ran out, officials said on Sunday. A hospital spokesman said the vendor, who is responsible for resupplying oxygen, failed to arrive on time. The hospital receives its oxygen cylinders from a vendor in Rawalpindi, a city about 190 kilometres away, he added.

news_headline: Britain readies navy to protect fishing waters in case of no-deal Brexit
news_article: Four Royal Navy patrol ships will be ready on January 1 to help protect Britain's fishing waters in the event of a no-deal Brexit, the country's Ministry of Defence said. Conservative MP Tobias Ellwood described the threat of using Royal Navy gunboats as "irresponsible". Earlier, PM Boris Johnson and the European Union said a no-deal outcome looked very likely.

news_headline: Oxford vaccine approval a triumph for British science: UK PM
news_article: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that the approval of COVID-19 vaccine developed by the University of Oxford and AstraZeneca is a "triumph for British science". Johnson added that the country will now "move to vaccinate as many people as quickly as possible". The UK on Wednesday became the first country in the world to approve the Oxford-AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine.

news_headline: Hong Kong activist Tony Chung convicted of insulting China's flag
news_article: Hong Kong activist Tony Chung has been convicted of insulting China's national flag and taking part in an unlawful assembly, offences that carry a maximum of three and five years respectively. Chung was found guilty of throwing the Chinese flag on the ground during a clash outside Hong Kong's legislature in May 2019. He'll be sentenced on December 29.

news_headline: Not expecting anything good from Biden: Russia's Dy Foreign Minister
news_article: Accusing the incoming US administration of "Russophobia", Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov said he wasn't expecting "anything good" from President-elect Joe Biden. He added that Russia wouldn't initiate any contact with Biden's transition team and will not make any "unilateral concessions". If US continued approaching Russia as a "strategic rival" then we would do the same, he said.

news_headline: 2 oil wells set ablaze using explosives in terrorist attack: Iraq
news_article: Two oil wells in an oilfield in northern Iraq were set ablaze using explosives in a "terrorist attack", the Oil Ministry said. Technical teams isolated the two burning wells and the overall production from the field wasn't affected, two sources said. The production from the two wells that were targeted didn't exceed 2,000 barrels per day (bpd), the ministry added.

news_headline: Kim Jong-un vaccinated against COVID-19; China supplied vaccine: Analyst
news_article: A US analyst has said North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and multiple other high-ranking officials within his family and leadership network have been vaccinated against coronavirus. Harry Kazianis, citing two unidentified Japanese intelligence sources, further said the experimental coronavirus vaccine was supplied by China. Kazianis is a North Korea expert at the Center for the National Interest.

news_headline: Clinical trials of Sputnik V which Russia says is 92% effective begin in India
news_article: Phase 2/3 clinical trials for Sputnik V, the first registered COVID-19 vaccine from Russia commenced in India today. Russian Direct Investment Fund and Dr Reddy’s Laboratories initiated the clinical trials of the vaccine, the Indian pharma company said. Last month, Russia had said Sputnik V vaccine is 92% effective at protecting people from COVID-19 according to the first interim analysis.

news_headline: California becomes 1st US state to report over 30 lakh COVID-19 cases
news_article: California on Tuesday became the first US state to report over 30 lakh coronavirus cases, according to the Johns Hopkins University tracker. The state has reported more than 33,700 coronavirus-related deaths, the tracker showed. California, which began COVID-19 vaccinations last month, has seen about 500 deaths and 40,000 new daily COVID-19 cases on an average in the past two weeks.

news_headline: We support HK authorities in fulfilling duties: China on mass arrests
news_article: Commenting on the arrest of over 50 pro-democracy activists under national security law, China on Wednesday said it supports Hong Kong authorities in the fulfilment of their duties. China added that Hong Kong people's rights and freedoms according to the law are not affected. The arrests represent the biggest crackdown on the opposition camp since the law's introduction last year.

news_headline: Number of people who died after receiving Pfizer vaccine in Norway rises to 29
news_article: The number of people who have died after receiving first doses of Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine in Norway has risen to 29. "All reported deaths are related to elderly people with serious basic disorders," the Norwegian Medicines Agency said. "Most people have experienced the expected side effects of the vaccine, such as nausea and vomiting...and worsening of their underlying condition," it added.

news_headline: France, NZ criticise China's fake pic of Aus soldier killing child
news_article: France and New Zealand have joined Australia in criticising China after a Chinese government spokesman posted a fake image of an Australian soldier murdering a child with the Afghan Flag in the background. The French government described the tweet as unworthy of diplomatic methods. New Zealand has directly raised its concerns with China over the image, PM Jacinda Ardern said.

news_headline: France to investigate 76 mosques suspected of 'separatism'
news_article: France will investigate 76 mosques suspected of fomenting Islamist ideology as part of its action against "separatism", Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin said. Where suspicions are confirmed, the mosque will be closed down, he added. The action comes after several Islamist attacks in France recently, including the beheading of a teacher who had shown his class caricatures of Prophet Muhammad.

news_headline: Millionaire books helicopter ride to eat burgers at outlet 725 km away
news_article: A Russian millionaire on vacation in Crimea booked a helicopter ride to eat burgers at the nearest McDonald's outlet which was 725 kilometres away. "My girlfriend and I were tired of organic food," Viktor Martynov said. According to a report, his order at the outlet cost around £49 (over ₹4,800) and the two-way ride cost around £2,000 (nearly ₹2 lakh).

news_headline: Violence never wins: Pence after Trump supporters stormed US Capitol
news_article: Condemning the violence at the US Capitol by Trump supporters in the "strongest possible terms", Vice President Mike Pence said that "violence never wins, freedom does". "To those who wreaked havoc in our Capitol today, You did not win," Pence added. President Donald Trump's supporters had stormed the Capitol in an attempt to block certification of the presidential election results.

news_headline: Death toll from earthquake in Indonesia rises to 73
news_article: The death toll after an earthquake hit Indonesia's West Sulawesi province rose to 73 on Sunday, its disaster mitigation agency said. Over 820 have been injured and over 27,800 left their homes to seek shelter in either the mountains or evacuation centres, it added. Police and military officers have been deployed to prevent looting in the region, it further said.

news_headline: Stand by my statement: Pak MP on IAF pilot Abhinandan's release
news_article: Pakistan MP Ayaz Sadiq on Saturday said that he stands by his statement in which he recounted why Pakistan released IAF pilot Abhinandan Varthaman. Sadiq had claimed, "Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi said for God's sake let Abhinandan go, India's about to attack Pakistan at 9 pm." Earlier, Information Minister Shibli Faraz said, "Remarks by Ayaz Sadiq are beyond apology."

news_headline: Lebanon's PM charged over Beirut explosion that killed 200 people
news_article: Lebanon's investigating judge has charged caretaker PM Hassan Diab with negligence over the Beirut port explosion that killed nearly 200 people in August. Former finance minister Ali Khalil and former public works ministers Ghazi Zeaiter and Youssef Fenianos have also been charged. The explosion was caused by the ignition of a large stockpile of ammonium nitrate stored at the port.

news_headline: Photographer posts pic of deer with arrow through head, calls for new law
news_article: Lee-Anne Carver, a Canadian wildlife photographer, has posted a picture of a deer with an arrow through his head. "It was disturbing, startling and crushing...For now, allow me to say the arrow missed all vitals. His skull protected him," she said. Carver spoke about advocating for a new law that could make it illegal to shoot urban deer.

news_headline: Woman gifts AK-47 to groom on wedding in Pak as people cheer; video viral
news_article: A video has gone viral on social media, showing a groom in Pakistan getting an AK-47 rifle as a wedding gift from a woman who's reported to be his mother-in-law. The video shows the woman giving the rifle to the groom amid cheers from the crowd. "That's the reason why Pakistan is the epicentre of terror," a Twitter user reacted.

news_headline: Spain classifies Madrid, other storm-hit regions as disaster zones
news_article: Spain on Tuesday classified capital Madrid and other regions struck by Storm Filomena, the worst snowstorm to strike the country in 50 years, as disaster zones. The move will trigger emergency subsidies and other support measures from the government. This came as Madrid's regional government said the rains predicted for Wednesday would likely "cause floods when all...ice begins to melt".

news_headline: BLM protesters would have been treated differently than Capitol rioters: Biden
news_article: US President-elect Joe Biden has said, "No one can tell me that if it was a group of Black Lives Matter protesters yesterday, they wouldn't have been treated very differently than the mob that stormed the Capitol." "We all know that's true—and it's unacceptable," he added. On Wednesday, President Donald Trump's supporters stormed US Capitol.

news_headline: Worried about insider attack at Biden's inauguration: US defence officials
news_article: US defence officials have said they are worried about an insider attack or other threat from service members involved in securing President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration. The FBI is screening all of the 25,000 National Guard troops coming into Washington DC for the event. Army Secretary Ryan McCarthy warned commanders to be on the lookout for any problems within their ranks.

news_headline: Bharat Biotech applies for COVID-19 vaccine trial in Bangladesh
news_article: Bharat Biotech has applied to conduct trials in Bangladesh for its COVID-19 vaccine, Covaxin, that was recently approved for emergency use in India. Mahmood-uz-Jahan, a director at the government-run Bangladesh Medical Research Council, said that the ethics committee will review the application. If granted approval, this would be the first trial of any COVID-19 vaccine in Bangladesh.

news_headline: Brazil becomes 2nd country to record over 2 lakh COVID-19 deaths
news_article: Brazil on Thursday became the second country after the US to record over two lakh COVID-19 deaths. With 1,524 fatalities in the last 24 hours, the total COVID-19 death toll in Brazil reached 200,498, the country's Health Ministry said. Brazil's coronavirus cases increased to 7,961,673 after it reported 87,843 new cases during the same period, the third-highest cases globally.

news_headline: Chinese firm's COVID-19 vaccine is 86% effective: UAE
news_article: A COVID-19 vaccine developed by Chinese state-owned pharmaceutical company Sinopharm is 86% effective, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), citing an interim analysis of late-stage clinical trials, said on Wednesday. The analysis shows 100% effectiveness in preventing moderate and severe cases of the disease, it added. It also shows no serious safety concerns, the UAE further said.

news_headline: US election was like that of a 'third world country': Trump
news_article: US President Donald Trump compared presidential election in the US to that of a "third world country", reiterating his claims about voter fraud. "It was a rigged election...I think the case has been made, and now we find out what we can do about it. You'll see a lot of big things happening the next couple of days," Trump said.

news_headline: Israel to share data with Pfizer in return for COVID-19 vaccine doses
news_article: According to a bilateral agreement, Israel will share the medical data gathered from its vaccination drive with Pfizer in return for coronavirus vaccine doses. The objective is to analyse epidemiological data to determine at what point herd immunity is achieved during the vaccination drive, the agreement said. Israeli Health Minister Yuli Edelstein has called it a "classical win-win" situation.

news_headline: Trump leaves office with lowest approval rating of his presidency at 34%
news_article: US President Donald Trump's approval rating dropped to 34%, the lowest rating of his presidency, according to a Gallup poll. The survey showed that Trump's rating had fallen 12 percentage points since before the November 3 presidential election. Trump's average approval rating across his term is 41%, four points lower than any of his predecessors since Gallup began gathering data.

news_headline: China to provide COVID-19 vaccine for free to all its citizens
news_article: China will provide COVID-19 vaccine free of cost to its citizens once it becomes available for the general public, government authorities said on Saturday. China has administered over 90 lakh COVID-19 vaccine doses, with over 70 lakh administered since mid-December. Last month, China approved COVID-19 vaccine from state-owned Sinopharm for general use, making it the country's first approved shot.

news_headline: Voice of desperation: Kamala Harris on Trump's Georgia phone call
news_article: US Vice President-elect Kamala Harris has said that President Donald Trump's phone call with Georgia's top election official showed Trump's "voice of desperation". "It was bald-faced, bold abuse of power," she added. In the audio of the call that went viral, Trump pressurised the official to "find" enough votes to overturn his defeat in Georgia in the November 3 election.

news_headline: Nepal's Parliament dissolved two years ahead of its normal tenure
news_article: Nepal President Bidya Devi Bhandari has accepted Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli's proposal to dissolve the Parliament two years ahead of its normal tenure. This comes amid a power tussle within the ruling Nepal Communist Party. Oli took the decision after a meeting at his residence as talks with party co-chairman and leader Pushpa Kamal Dahal Prachanda failed.

news_headline: Linking religion to terrorism a mistake: Widodo on Macron's remarks
news_article: Indonesian President Joko Widodo on Saturday condemned the knife attack in France's Nice, however, he said that remarks by President Emmanuel Macron had "insulted Islam" and "hurt the unity of Muslims everywhere". "Linking religion to acts of terrorism is a massive mistake," he added. Macron had termed the knife attack in which a woman was beheaded as "Islamist terrorist attack".

news_headline: Jailed Navalny releases investigation into Putin's '$1.36 bn palace'
news_article: Jailed Russian opposition leader Alexey Navalny and his team have released a video investigation alleging that President Vladimir Putin owns a 100 billion-rubles ($1.36 billion) Black Sea palace. The video claims the palace contains a casino, theatre, ornate interiors and an underground ice rink. Russian government spokesman Dmitry Peskov said the palace allegations were old and untrue.

news_headline: FBI warns of armed protests being planned in all US states: Report
news_article: The FBI has warned that armed protests are being planned at all 50 state capitols and the US Capitol in Washington, DC in the run-up to President-elect Joe Biden's January 20 inauguration, reports said. The warning comes after President Donald Trump's supporters stormed the Capitol last week. Trump had addressed his supporters ahead of the violence.

news_headline: Gorillas test positive for COVID-19 at US zoo; had been coughing
news_article: Several gorillas at US' San Diego Zoo Safari Park have tested positive for coronavirus in what is believed to be the first known cases among such primates in the world. The safari park tested faeces of the gorillas after two apes began coughing. Positive test results were confirmed by US Department of Agriculture National Veterinary Services Laboratories in three gorillas.

news_headline: 82-yr-old UK patient on dialysis becomes 1st in world to get Oxford COVID-19 vaccine
news_article: An 82-year-old man has become the first person in the world to receive Oxford-AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine since it was approved for use. Brian Pinker, a patient on dialysis for kidney disease, was the first to receive it on Monday. "I'm so pleased to be getting the...vaccine...and really proud it is one that was invented in Oxford," he stated.

news_headline: UAE vaccinates over 12 lakh people against coronavirus
news_article: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) on Wednesday said that it has vaccinated 12.75 lakh people against coronavirus so far. "We hope that with vaccinations picking up pace, we'll reach the point of full recovery in the shortest possible time," Abu Dhabi Crown Prince Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan tweeted. The UAE had started the vaccination drive last month.

news_headline: US approves potential sale of 3,000 bombs worth $290mn to S Arabia
news_article: The US State Department on Tuesday approved a potential sale of 3,000 bombs worth $290 million to Saudi Arabia. "The proposed sale will improve Saudi Arabia's capability to meet current and future threats by increasing its stocks of long-range, precision air-to-ground munitions," the Pentagon said. The potential sale comes in the final days of US President Donald Trump's term.

news_headline: Man held with 500 rounds of ammunition near Capitol ahead of Biden's inauguration
news_article: Ahead of US President-elect Joe Biden's oath-taking ceremony, a man from Virginia has been arrested at the inauguration checkpoint in Washington, DC, for carrying an unregistered handgun with over 500 rounds of ammunition in his car. He was denied passage through the checkpoint, located half a mile from the Capitol, police said. He was also carrying an "unauthorised" inauguration pass.

news_headline: Russia to join naval drills with NATO members for 1st time in 10 yrs
news_article: Russia on Thursday said that its navy will take part in AMAN-2021 anti-piracy drills off the coast of Pakistan in February 2021 along with the navies of 30 other countries, including NATO members. It will be the first time in 10 years that Russian vessels will take part in exercises alongside NATO ships, the TASS news agency reported.

news_headline: Harris, Biden pay tribute to Americans who died of COVID-19
news_article: On the eve of the inauguration, US President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris paid tribute to Americans who have died of COVID-19. "To heal, we must remember...It's hard sometimes to remember, but that's how we heal. It's important to do that as a nation," Biden said during the vigil. The US has reported over 4 lakh coronavirus-related deaths.

news_headline: UK MP apologises for tweet supporting pro-Khalistan group banned by India
news_article: British Labour MP Taiwo Owatemi has apologised after extending support to pro-Khalistan group Sikhs for Justice (SFJ), which is banned by India. She explained that a small number of individuals emailed her to post a suggested tweet supporting the group. Owatemi said that a staff member posted the tweet from her Twitter account for the group without her knowledge.

news_headline: End Trump administration's rogue regime: Iran FM Zarif to Biden
news_article: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif has asked US President-elect Joe Biden to end the Trump administration's "rogue regime" and lift sanctions targeting Iran's oil and financial sectors. Zarif added that Iran would not renegotiate the 2015 nuclear deal. "The deal was about give and take, it wasn't about one side asking and the other side giving," he further said.

news_headline: Bolivia signs deal with India's Serum Institute for 50L vaccine doses
news_article: The Bolivian government has signed a contract with Serum Institute of India (SII) for the supply of 50 lakh doses of AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine. Bolivian President Luis Arce said the first 10 lakh AstraZeneca doses will arrive in Bolivia in April. The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) approved the Covishield vaccine for emergency use in India on January 3.

news_headline: Police search for woman after ₹95 crore in cash missing from S Korea casino
news_article: South Korean police are on the hunt for a female casino executive who disappeared after her employer discovered $13 million (over ₹95 crore) in cash missing from the resort's coffer. The employee did not return to work after going on vacation. Police secured surveillance camera footage but the video around the time the funds may have disappeared was erased.

news_headline: Explosion in Rawalpindi market leaves 25 injured
news_article: At least 25 people were injured in an explosion near a police station in a market in Pakistan's Rawalpindi city on Sunday, officials said. Initial reports suggested that it was a hand grenade attack but a police official said it was too soon to ascertain the nature of the blast. The affected area in the market has been cordoned off.

news_headline: Pak court jails 3 for vandalising Gurdwara Nankana Sahib last year
news_article: A court in Pakistan on Tuesday sentenced three people up to two years in prison for vandalising Gurdwara Nankana Sahib last year. Imran Chishti, the main culprit, was sentenced to two years in jail and fined PKR 10,000 (over ₹4,560), a court official said. The other two culprits were sentenced to six months in jail, the official added.

news_headline: Canada considers adding far-right group to terror list over US riots
news_article: Canada is considering designating far-right group Proud Boys as a terrorist organisation alongside groups like al-Qaeda and ISIS, following their role in last week's US Capitol riots. Canada's Public Safety Minister Bill Blair said his office was closely watching the group and the "ideologically-motivated violent extremists" within the group. The group is "hateful and dangerous", Blair added.

news_headline: Putin critic Navalny calls for street protests after being jailed
news_article: Russian President Vladimir Putin's critic Alexey Navalny has called for street protests after he was remanded in pre-trial detention for 30 days. "Don't be afraid, take to the streets. Don't go out for me, go out for yourself and your future," Navalny said in a Twitter video. He was arrested for multiple parole violations after landing in Moscow.

news_headline: India to export COVID-19 vaccines to 6 countries from Jan 20
news_article: The Ministry of External Affairs has announced that India will export COVID-19 vaccines to Bhutan, Maldives, Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar and Seychelles from Wednesday. The government received several requests for the supply of Indian manufactured vaccines, the MEA added. "India is deeply honoured to be a long-trusted partner in meeting the healthcare needs of the global community," PM Modi said.

news_headline: What is top-secret Russian 'Doomsday Plane' that was raided by thieves?
news_article: A top-secret military aircraft known as the 'Doomsday Plane', which was recently raided by thieves, is designed to carry top officials in the event of a nuclear attack. The Ilyushin Il-80 plane can take off from any civil or military airfield, according to state media. It has a powerful engine, modern communication facilities and can remain airborne for several days.

news_headline: Ugandan President Museveni wins sixth term as rival alleges fraud
news_article: Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni has been re-elected for a sixth term in a vote his rival Bobi Wine rejected as rigged. Wine denounced the election results as "complete fraud" and asked citizens to reject them as Museveni refuted the allegations. Museveni won 5.85 million votes, or 58.6%, while Wine had 3.48 million votes (34.8%), the electoral commission said.

news_headline: North Korea unveils new submarine-launched ballistic missile
news_article: North Korea has unveiled a new submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) that the state media described as "the world's most powerful weapon". Rockets with a "powerful striking capability" were also on display at a parade overseen by leader Kim Jong-un. The parade follows the ruling party's first congress since 2016, where Kim called the US his country's "biggest enemy".

news_headline: Thai men and women hold crop top protests with anti-monarchy slogans on belly
news_article: Some protest leaders in Thailand dressed in crop tops and paraded at a Bangkok shopping mall in a jibe against King Maha Vajiralongkorn to demand the repeal of the law against insulting the monarchy. Several activists also had anti-monarchy slogans written on their belly. Pictures of the king wearing a crop top had gone viral online a few years ago.

news_headline: Portugal's President Marcelo Rebelo tests positive for COVID-19
news_article: Portugal's President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa has tested positive for coronavirus but has no symptoms, his office said on Monday. The 72-year-old, who is seeking a second term in the presidential election scheduled for January 24, has cancelled all public appearances and will self-isolate at his official residence, it added. Portugal has reported over 4.8 lakh COVID-19 cases so far.

news_headline: Pak to offer free COVID-19 vaccine to all its residents
news_article: Pakistan will provide the coronavirus vaccine free of cost to its residents and start vaccination drive by April next year, Parliamentary Secretary for National Health Services Nausheen Hamid said. The vaccine will be given to frontline health workers and people over the age of 60 in the first phase, she added. COVID-19 has infected over 4 lakh people in Pakistan.

news_headline: 95% of vaccines given around world are in 10 countries: WHO
news_article: Ten countries account for 95% of the 2.35 crore coronavirus vaccine doses administered across the world, the head of WHO's European office, Dr Hans Kluge, said. In response, the WHO has called for more equitable distribution. In terms of total doses, the top countries are the US, China, the UK, Israel, the UAE, Italy, Russia, Germany, Spain and Canada.

news_headline: Heard rioters saying they want to 'hang Pence' during Capitol riots: Photographer
news_article: Reuters photographer Jim Bourg, who was covering the US Capitol riot, said that he heard at least three different rioters say that they "hoped to find Vice President Mike Pence and execute him by hanging him from a Capitol Hill tree as a traitor". "Many more were just talking about how the VP should be executed," he added.

news_headline: Some will sit at family tables missing a familiar face: WHO chief in Xmas message
news_article: In a message for Christmas, WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said we mustn't squander the sacrifices made to protect us from coronavirus pandemic by people or their families "who, this holiday season, will sit at family tables missing a familiar face". "Millions of people are today making great, heart-wrenching sacrifices by staying apart to stay safe," he added.

news_headline: New UK COVID-19 variant found in at least 60 countries: WHO
news_article: The World Health Organization (WHO) has said the new coronavirus variant that emerged in the UK has been found in at least 60 countries. The UK identified the new COVID-19 variant, that it said is 70% more transmissible, on December 14, 2020. The WHO further said that the South African-identified coronavirus variant has been detected in 23 countries and territories.

news_headline: South Korea is holding $7 bn in Iranian funds hostage: Iran
news_article: Denying that it's holding a South Korean ship and its crew as hostages, Iran said, "[South] Korea's government...is holding $7 billion, which belongs to us, hostage on baseless grounds." The Iranian funds have been frozen in South Korean banks due to US sanctions. South Korea said that it would send a delegation to Iran to try to free the ship.

news_headline: Just 25 COVID-19 vaccine doses given across all poor countries: WHO
news_article: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has said that only 25 COVID-19 vaccine doses have been administered across all poor countries compared with 39 million in 49 higher-income countries. Guinea is the only low-income country to have delivered shots so far. It provided doses of the Russian Sputnik V vaccine to 25 people last week, including its president.

news_headline: Not a cricket match: Vir Das after Indian Flag spotted at US Capitol protests
news_article: After Indian Flag was spotted at US Capitol protests, comedian Vir Das tweeted, "Dear random Indian dude waving Indian Flag...Every large crowd is not a cricket match!" Meanwhile, a Twitter user wrote, "Not the place where we'd like to see our Indian Flag." BJP MP Varun Gandhi tweeted, "This is one fight we definitely don’t need to participate in."

news_headline: Any vaccine adverse effects up to national agencies to review: WHO
news_article: The WHO has said that any adverse effects of COVID-19 vaccines are up to national agencies to review. The organisation was responding to questions on Britain's regulatory agency warning people with a history of anaphylaxis to avoid the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine. "One vaccine may not be suitable for particular individuals, but you may well find another vaccine is," WHO added.

news_headline: Boeing 737 plane in Indonesia falls 10,000 ft within 5 minutes, loses contact
news_article: Sriwijaya Air Flight 182 lost contact with Indonesia's aviation authorities minutes after taking off from capital Jakarta, officials have said. The plane was a Boeing 737-500 series and it dropped from almost 11,000 feet to 250 feet within five minutes before disappearing from the radar. The plane was Pontianak-bound.

news_headline: Car bomb blast kills at least 30 Afghan security force personnel
news_article: A car bomb blast in Afghanistan's central province of Ghazni has killed at least 30 Afghan security force members and injured 24 others on Sunday, officials said. The blast targeted a compound of the public protection force, a wing of the Afghan security forces, local officials said. Civilian residences around the compound were also damaged in the blast, they added.

news_headline: 800 Indian peacekeepers awarded medals for their service in S Sudan
news_article: More than 800 Indian peacekeepers, including a sole woman officer, have been awarded medals for their service for the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS). The Indian battalion in Upper Nile State provides veterinary services to local communities. The peacekeepers have treated thousands of animals and trained 226 Community Animal Health Workers despite the harsh conditions, UNMISS said.

news_headline: Int'l experts hold 1st meeting with China on COVID-19 origin: WHO
news_article: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said that international experts held their first virtual meeting with Chinese counterparts on Friday to probe the animal origins of novel coronavirus. The UN will continue to establish origins of the virus "to prevent future outbreaks", he added. In July, the WHO had sent a team to China to lay the groundwork for the probe.

news_headline: Joe Biden, Kamala Harris named TIME's 2020 Person of the Year
news_article: US President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris have been named TIME's 2020 Person of the Year. "For changing American story, for showing that forces of empathy are greater than the furies of division, for sharing a vision of healing in a grieving world, Biden and Harris are TIME's 2020 Person of the Year," TIME editor-in-chief Edward Felsenthal wrote.

news_headline: 1st doses of COVID-19 vaccines could be available in Dec, Jan: Fauci
news_article: Top US infectious diseases expert Dr Anthony Fauci said if everything goes well, the first doses of COVID-19 vaccines will be available to some high-risk Americans in late December or early January. "The first interim look (at trial results) should be, we hope, within the next few weeks," he added. US has reported over 89 lakh COVID-19 cases so far.

news_headline: US President-elect Biden receives COVID-19 vaccine on live TV
news_article: US President-elect Joe Biden received a dose of the Pfizer coronavirus vaccine on live television on Monday, saying he was taking the vaccine to show Americans it's "safe to take". He added that the Trump administration "deserves some credit" for launching the mass vaccination programme. Biden's wife Jill also received a dose of the Pfizer vaccine.

news_headline: New COVID-19 strain can be prevented using same interventions: WHO
news_article: The spread of new coronavirus strain can be prevented using the same interventions that also work for the viruses that are circulating around, said Maria Van Kerkhove, WHO technical lead for COVID-19. "This is physical distancing, making sure we avoid crowded spaces," she added. "We have to work a little bit harder as the new variant is spreading," she said.

news_headline: India planning surgical strike against us: Pakistan
news_article: Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has claimed that India is planning a surgical strike on its neighbouring country. "I have learnt through our intelligence sources...This is a serious development and I also have knowledge that they have tried to seek approval from...their partners," he stated. Qureshi said this during a press conference in Abu Dhabi on Friday.

news_headline: Trump signs bill to rename post office after slain Sikh police officer
news_article: US President Donald Trump signed a bill into law to rename a Houston post office after Indian-American police officer Sandeep Singh Dhaliwal, who was gunned down in an ambush last year. The bill passed the Senate earlier this month. It's the second US post office to be named after an Indian-American, first being named after Congressman Dalip Saund in California.

news_headline: We will be back in some form: Donald Trump in final address as US President
news_article: In his final speech as US President, Donald Trump told his supporters, "We will be back in some form." He added, "We love the American people and again it has been something very special." He further said, "I want to thank all the great people of Washington, DC...all of the people that we worked with to put this miracle together."

news_headline: Pakistan's coronavirus cases exceed 4 lakh-mark
news_article: Pakistan's total COVID-19 cases on Tuesday rose to 4,00,482 after 2,458 new cases were reported in the past 24 hours, the country's Health Ministry said. The total COVID-19 death toll increased to 8,091 with 66 new deaths being reported during the same period, it added. Pakistan is currently dealing with the second wave of COVID-19 infections.

news_headline: Ex-Iranian VP sentenced to 2 yrs in jail for leaking classified info
news_article: Former Iranian Vice President Shahindokht Mowlaverdi has been sentenced to two years in prison for leaking classified information to foreign parties, state media reports said. "It's a preliminary verdict...There is a 20-day window for reconsideration and I'll certainly appeal," she said. Separately, Mowlaverdi was given another six months in prison for "propaganda" against Iran's ruling system.

news_headline: US court dismisses $100 million lawsuit against PM Modi, Amit Shah
news_article: A US court has dismissed a $100 million lawsuit filed against Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Home Minister Amit Shah and Lieutenant General Kanwal Jeet Singh Dhillon. The court dismissed the case after Kashmir Khalistan Referendum Front failed to appear at two hearings. The lawsuit was filed on September 19, 2019 over the abrogation of Article 370 in Jammu and Kashmir.

news_headline: France to build new nuclear-powered aircraft carrier
news_article: France will build a new nuclear-powered aircraft carrier that'll replace its Charles de Gaulle carrier by 2038, French President Emmanuel Macron said. The new carrier will be about 70,000 tonnes and 300 metres long. Macron framed the decision to use nuclear reactors to propel the warship as part of France's climate strategy, stressing its lower emissions compared to diesel fuel.

news_headline: South Korea approves single test for coronavirus and flu
news_article: South Korean health officials have approved a new test that is designed to detect both COVID-19 and seasonal influenza from the same samples. The new test is an evolved version of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test that is used to detect COVID-19. The diagnosis will reduce the burden of medical workers, a senior Health Ministry official said.

news_headline: UN chief Antonio Guterres announces bid for 2nd five-year term
news_article: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres on Monday officially declared that he is seeking a second five-year term. Guterres, whose current term ends on December 31, said in a letter to General Assembly President Volkan Bozkir, "It would be my honour to continue to serve the organisation in pursuing its purposes and fulfilling its noble objectives."

news_headline: 36 British MPs write to UK govt in support of farmers' protest in India
news_article: Thirty-six UK Members of Parliament have written to the country's Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab seeking an intervention of the government on the farmers' issue in India. Citing that the new farm laws are being described as "death warrant", the MPs said, "This is an issue of particular concern to Sikhs in the UK and those linked to Punjab."

news_headline: Some of those involved in nuclear scientist's killing held: Iran
news_article: Iran has arrested some of the people involved in last month's assassination of the country's most senior nuclear scientist Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, state media, citing an official, reported. However, the official declined to provide any further details on the detentions. The official alleged that Israel carried out the assassination with the help of the US.

news_headline: Brazil private clinics seek deal with Bharat Biotech for vaccine
news_article: The Brazilian Association of Vaccine Clinics (ABCVAC) has said that it is negotiating with Indian firm Bharat Biotech to buy 50 lakh doses of its COVID-19 vaccine, Covaxin. Any final deal would be subject to approval by Brazil's health regulator, ANVISA. On Sunday, India granted emergency use approval for Covaxin, which is currently under Phase 3 clinical trials.

news_headline: Facebook-backed cryptocurrency Libra renamed as Diem
news_article: Facebook-backed cryptocurrency Libra has been rebranded as Diem in an effort to reinforce the organisation's independence and to gain regulatory approval. "The original name was tied to an early iteration of the project that received a difficult reception from regulators," Diem Association CEO Stuart Levey told Reuters. Diem aims to initially launch a single dollar-backed digital coin, he added.

news_headline: 2.3 mn children in Tigray need humanitarian assistance: UNICEF
news_article: The ongoing conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray region has left some 2.3 million children in urgent need of assistance, UNICEF executive director Henrietta Fore said. Some 12,000 children living in camps and registration centres are at risk, she added. Fore further said that every effort should be made to ensure that children are "protected from recruitment and use in the conflict".

news_headline: Iran advances bill to stop nuclear inspections after scientist’s killing
news_article: The Iranian Parliament has advanced a bill that would end UN inspections of its nuclear facilities in response to the assassination of the country's most senior nuclear scientist Mohsen Fakhrizadeh. The bill also requires Iran to boost its uranium enrichment. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has accused Israel of assassinating Fakhrizadeh near the country's capital Tehran last week.

news_headline: How has Mount Everest's height varied over the years?
news_article: In 1954, the Survey of India had estimated Mount Everest’s height to be 8,848 metres (29,028 feet) which was widely accepted. An Italian survey in 1987 determined 8,872 metres as its height. In 1999, an American survey estimated Mount Everest’s height to be 8,850 metres. A Chinese measurement in 2005 estimated that Mount Everest’s height was 8,844.43 metres.

news_headline: Ant Group's IPO may not be revived before 2022: Report
news_article: Jack Ma-owned Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO) may not be revived before 2022 as the company is still in the early stages of reviewing changes needed to appease the regulators, officials told Bloomberg. There's so much work needed and some rules are not yet spelled out, they added. Ant's $35-billion IPO was poised to become the largest IPO ever.

news_headline: Be strong in backing Taiwan against China: Japan minister to Biden
news_article: Calling the island's safety a "red line", Japan's Deputy Defence Minister Yasuhide Nakayama urged US President-elect Joe Biden to "be strong" in backing Taiwan against China. We're concerned that China would expand its "aggressive stance" into Taiwan, he added. An official in Biden's team said the President-elect believes US support for Taiwan "must remain strong, principled, and bipartisan".

news_headline: Google, FB, Microsoft pause political donations after US Capitol attack
news_article: Google, Facebook and Microsoft said that they are temporarily suspending all political donations to both the Democratic and Republican party in the US. Their decision comes after the attack at US Capitol. While Facebook said it'll be pausing political donations for at least the current quarter, Google and Microsoft said they'll reassess their policies and the implications of the attack.

news_headline: Negative COVID-19 test must for arriving int'l air passengers: US
news_article: US has said that it'll require all incoming passengers to test negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of departure. Those under the age of two and passengers transiting through US are exempt from the rule. "Testing before and after travel is a critical layer to slow the introduction and spread of coronavirus," US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.

news_headline: Be vigilant: France to its citizens around the world after attacks
news_article: French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian on Friday asked French citizens around the world to be vigilant as "there are threats everywhere". He added that the government has instructed its embassies around the world to tighten security in the wake of recent attacks in Nice and Paris. Meanwhile, French President Emmanuel Macron held a crisis meeting with top ministers.

news_headline: Redouble control in Europe: WHO after new COVID-19 strain found in UK
news_article: The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged European countries to "redouble their control and prevention approaches" to coronavirus after a new COVID-19 strain was found in the UK. Several European countries have decided to suspend all flights from the UK in response. WHO also urged its members to "increase...sequencing of SARS-CoV-2 viruses where possible" and share the data internationally.

news_headline: Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine to be rolled out in UK from January 4
news_article: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine will be rolled out in the UK from January 4 as hundreds of thousands of doses will be ready for next week, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said. The vaccine was approved for use in the UK on Wednesday. The 100 million doses of the vaccine purchased by the UK will cover the whole adult population, Hancock added.

news_headline: Fire at Russian fireworks factory sends thousands of rockets into sky; video surfaces
news_article: A fireworks factory in Russia caught fire, setting off multiple explosions and sending thousands of rockets into the night sky. A video of the incident has also surfaced online showing several firefighters trying to control the situation amid non-stop fireworks. Over 400 firefighters had arrived at the spot to control the blaze, according to reports.

news_headline: Delhi startup builds tech to do COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 cr samples per week
news_article: Delhi-based IT startup Thalamus Irwine claims to have developed an artificial intelligence and IoT-based solution that can complete a COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 crore samples in one week. It has also partnered with state-run ITI to host its data. Serosurveys can help track the geographic spread of the virus by analysing antibodies in blood samples.

news_headline: Iran journalist who inspired 2017 nationwide protests executed
news_article: Iranian authorities on Saturday executed journalist Ruhollah Zam over his online work that helped inspire nationwide economic protests in 2017. A court had sentenced Zam to death in June after he was found guilty of "corruption on earth", one of the country's most serious offences. Zam had been living in exile in France but was arrested in October last year.

news_headline: Niraj Antani becomes 1st Indian-American to be elected to Ohio Senate
news_article: Niraj Antani, a Republican, has become the first Indian-American to be elected to the Ohio state Senate. "I am truly grateful to have won the election for State Senator! I am so thankful for all of my voters, contributors, team, and supporters," the 29-year-old tweeted. Antani has defeated Democratic Party's Mark Fogel to be elected from Ohio Senate's 6th District.

news_headline: Happy that 'lawless' Trump is leaving White House: Iran President
news_article: Calling US President Donald Trump "lawless" and a "terrorist", Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Wednesday said that he is happy that Trump is leaving the White House. However, Rouhani added that he was not "overjoyed about Mr. Biden's arrival". US President-elect Joe Biden is set to take office on January 20 as the 46th president of the United States.

news_headline: Google's decision horrible way to handle situation: Parler CEO on app ban
news_article: Parler CEO John Matze said Google removing Parler from its store for its alleged role in US Capitol violence was a "horrible way to handle" the situation. Parler was allegedly used by rioters. Matze also targeted US lawmaker Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez who sought action against Parler. He called her hypocritical, adding she had encouraged rioting from left-leaning protestors in the past.

news_headline: Google acquires firm that can turn old PCs into Chrome devices
news_article: Google has acquired Neverware, a company that turns old PCs into Chrome devices, for an undisclosed amount. Neverware on its website said the company and its software CloudReady are now part of Google and the Chrome OS team. CloudReady converts old PCs into a system that runs Chrome OS, which is a lighter software and thereby reduces e-waste.

news_headline: Monitoring Brahmaputra river amid reports of Chinese construction: India
news_article: India is "carefully monitoring all developments" on the Brahmaputra river after reports said China was looking to build a hydropower project on it, MEA spokesperson Anurag Srivastava said. "The government has consistently conveyed its...concerns to the Chinese authorities," he added. India has urged them to ensure interests of downstream states "aren't harmed" by upstream areas, he further said.

news_headline: Saddened by this mob violence: Mark Zuckerberg on US Capitol violence
news_article: Condemning the violence that occurred at the US Capitol, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said that it was "a dark moment" in US history. "I'm personally saddened by this mob violence - which is exactly what this is," Zuckerberg wrote in a memo to his staff. He further said that peaceful transition of power is critical to the functioning of democracy.

news_headline: Wistron could not cope with rapid scaling up of manpower: Govt report
news_article: Apple supplier Wistron's Karnataka plant couldn't cope up with the rapid scaling up of manpower, Reuters reported quoting a government report. Its manpower rose to 10,500 workers from the permitted 5,000 in a short span of time. Wistron also failed to fix a glitch in its attendance system which caused employees' presence to be registered incorrectly, the report added.

news_headline: S'pore police to be able to access contact tracing data for criminal probes
news_article: Singapore police will be able to use data obtained by Singapore's coronavirus contact-tracing technology for criminal investigations. Singapore uses an app, TraceTogether, and a device to trace contacts. Home affairs minister Desmond Tan said the police is empowered under the Criminal Procedure Code to obtain any data, and that includes the TraceTogether data.

news_headline: UN troops retake rebel-held city in Central African Republic
news_article: United Nations (UN) peacekeeping troops have retaken the control of Bangassou city from rebels in the Central African Republic (CAR), a spokesman said. The rebels fled the city after the UN peacekeeping force issued an ultimatum to the rebels on Friday. The rebels belong to armed groups waging an offensive against President Faustin Archange Touadera-led government.

news_headline: WHO chief should be probed over genocide in Ethiopia: Economist
news_article: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus should be probed over genocide in Ethiopia, Nobel Peace Prize nominee David Steinman said in a complaint to International Criminal Court. He "was a crucial decision-maker in relation to...actions that included killing...and torturing Ethiopians", Steinman said. Ghebreyesus shared control over Ethiopia's security forces between 2013 and 2015, Steinman alleged.

news_headline: Wuhan lab scientists may have had COVID-19 before first reported cases: US
news_article: The US has claimed that researchers inside the Wuhan lab became sick in autumn 2019, before the first identified case of COVID-19. The US said they had symptoms consistent with both COVID-19 and common seasonal illnesses. "This raises questions about the credibility of a senior researcher's public claim that there was 'zero infection' among the staff and students," it added.

news_headline: 820-foot-tall world's largest crane completes its biggest ever lift, pics surface
news_article: The world's largest crane completed its biggest ever lift today, hoisting a 575-ton steel cylinder into place at a nuclear site in the UK. The super-crane, nicknamed Big Carl, lifted the first of three massive steel rings which form a cylinder around the nuclear reactor being built near Bridgwater, Somerset. The crane can be 820-foot-high in its tallest configuration.

news_headline: Viral pic shows 3 exhausted medics resting on floor next to COVID-19 patient
news_article: A viral picture shows three medical students in protective suits resting on the floor next to a COVID-19 patient at an hospital in Russia's Sosnovy Bor. "My utmost gratitude to Rasul, Katya and Lyosha for taking an extra shift in an emergency," the chief nurse said. "We were exhausted...The hazard suit doesn't breath at all," one of them said.

news_headline: Apple removes app promoting 'secret' parties amid COVID-19 in US
news_article: Apple has removed an iOS app that promoted "secret gatherings" in New York City, which would have been illegal under current COVID-19 pandemic restrictions in US. Vybe Together gained exposure when a New York Times reporter tweeted about it, saying it promoted "COVID-unsafe large, indoor house parties". The app had a few thousand users, Vybe Together's Co-founder told The Verge.

news_headline: Google wins EU approval for $2.1 billion Fitbit deal
news_article: Google on Thursday won the European Union's antitrust approval for its $2.1 billion bid for Fitbit after it agreed to certain restrictions. Google pledged to maintain access for rival fitness and health apps and devices for 10 years. It also agreed to store the Fitbit user data separately from the Google data and to not use it for Google Ads.

news_headline: Amazon writes to SEBI, says Future Retail misleading public: Report
news_article: Amazon has complained to the SEBI that its local partner Future Retail misled public shareholders by saying it was complying with its contractual obligations to the e-commerce firm, a report said. Amazon had alleged that Future Group's $3.4-billion asset sale to Reliance Industries violated a 2019 contract. In a letter, Amazon urged the SEBI not to approve the deal.

news_headline: Ant Group's valuation could drop to $108 billion: Bloomberg
news_article: Ant Group's valuation could drop to $108 billion under the draft rules proposed by China, according to Bloomberg Intelligence. The proposals aimed at curbing market concentration in Chinese online payments market could reduce the value of Ant's Alipay service by half, the report stated. Ant Group's valuation was estimated to reach over $320 billion before its $35-billion IPO was suspended.

news_headline: Who was FC Kohli, 'father of Indian IT industry' who passed away at 96?
news_article: Faqir Chand Kohli, the founding CEO of TCS who was called the 'father of Indian IT/software industry', was born and raised in Peshawar. He received a bachelor's in electrical engineering from Canada's Queen's University and a master's degree from MIT. In 1951, he joined Tata Electric Companies (now Tata Power) and in 1968, he was tasked with running TCS.

news_headline: We pursue an independent foreign policy: India on Russia's comments
news_article: Responding to Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov's comments that US-led West was attempting to undermine its relations with New Delhi, India said, "Our relations with Russia stand on their own merits." "India has always pursued an independent foreign policy based on its national interest. India's relationship with each country is independent of its relations with third countries," it added.

news_headline: Joe Biden will be a president who represents the best in us: Harris
news_article: US Vice President-elect Kamala Harris on Saturday said that Joe Biden will be a president who "represents the best in us [America]" and will be a leader who's respected around the world. She added that Biden would be "a commander in chief who'll respect our troops and keep our country safe". Biden is set to take office on January 20.

news_headline: Spain's lower house approves bill legalising euthanasia
news_article: Spain's lower house of parliament has voted in favour of a bill that will legalise euthanasia, despite strong opposition from religious groups. The legislation allows patients with "serious and incurable" diseases that cause "unbearable" suffering to choose to end their lives. The bill will now go to the Senate for vote. Currently, euthanasia is legal in three European Union countries.

news_headline: South Korea shuts down winter tourism spots to curb COVID-19 spread
news_article: South Korea on Tuesday ordered for all ski resorts and winter tourism spots to be shut in a bid to curb the spread of COVID-19 in the country. This comes after Seoul and surrounding areas banned gatherings of more than four people over Christmas and New Year holidays. The country recorded its highest daily death toll from COVID-19 on Monday.

news_headline: China greatest threat to freedom worldwide since WWII: US Intel chief
news_article: US National Intelligence Director John Ratcliffe has said China is the "greatest threat to democracy and freedom" worldwide since World War Two. He also said China was growing its dominance by stealing US' intellectual property, replicating it and then replacing US firms in the market. Beijing intends to dominate US and the world "economically, militarily and technologically", Ratcliffe added.

news_headline: 6-yr-old in US spends ₹12 lakh on iPad game from mother's credit card
news_article: After a 41-year-old woman in US filed a fraud claim for charges made from her credit card, she discovered her six-year-old had ended up paying $16,293 (about ₹12 lakh) to Apple for purchases in a video game. Apple declined to refund the amount since she hadn't claimed it within 60 days. "There's a setting, you should've known," Apple told her.

news_headline: After Elon Musk, Oracle Founder Larry Ellison leaves California
news_article: Days after Elon Musk criticised California and confirmed that he's moving to Texas, Oracle's billionaire Founder Larry Ellison revealed that he is also leaving the state, for his personal island in Hawaii. "I'll be using...Zoom to work from the island of Lanai," he wrote to his employees. Oracle had confirmed its headquarters will move to Texas from Silicon Valley earlier.

news_headline: A very sad group of people is trying to disenfranchise my supporters: Trump
news_article: US President Donald Trump has said that "a very sad group of people" is trying to disenfranchise millions of his supporters who voted for him. "We were getting ready for a big celebration. We were winning everything, and all of a sudden that was just called off," Trump further said alleging fraud in the vote count.

news_headline: Apple, Amazon and Tesla supplier used forced Uighur labour: Report
news_article: Lens Technology, a company that supplies various parts to Apple, Amazon and Tesla, has been accused of using forced labour from thousands of Uighur workers in its Chinese factories. The evidence to the claims was available openly on the internet, the Tech Transparency Project claimed. "Apple has zero tolerance for forced labour," an Apple representative told The Washington Post.

news_headline: Trump must blame Russia for massive cyberattack on US: Biden
news_article: US President-elect Joe Biden on Tuesday said he had seen no evidence that the massive cyberattack against the US is under control and that the breach will not go unanswered once he takes office on January 20. He added that President Trump needs to blame Russia for the attack. The attack breached several government agencies and thousands of US companies.

news_headline: Nurse in Indonesia strips off PPE to have sex with Covid patient in toilet, suspended
news_article: A nurse at the Wisma Atlet Emergency Hospital in Indonesia's Jakarta has been suspended after admitting to stripping off his PPE to have sex with a COVID-19 positive patient in the hospital toilet. The patient uploaded a screenshot of WhatsApp messages between them after which an investigation took place. The pair are currently both in independent isolation.

news_headline: Nude pics of Thai King's mistress leaked, sent to anti-monarchy activists
news_article: More than 1,000 photographs, many of them nude, of King of Thailand's mistress Sineenat Wongvajirapakdi have been leaked and sent to anti-monarchy activists. The pictures were taken between 2012 and 2014. In September, King Maha Vajiralongkorn had reinstated Sineenat and returned the official titles and military rank to her, nearly a year after she was removed from the position.

news_headline: 60,000 koalas were killed or harmed in Australian bushfires: WWF
news_article: More than 60,000 koalas were killed, injured or displaced in Australian bushfires last summer, the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) has estimated. "That is a devastating number for a species that was already sliding towards extinction in Eastern Australia. We cannot afford to lose koalas on our watch," the WWF said.

news_headline: 23 die in Norway a short time after receiving 1st doses of Pfizer vaccine
news_article: Twenty-three people have died in Norway a short time after receiving first doses of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine, Norwegian officials said. Of those deaths, 13 have been autopsied, with the results suggesting that common side effects may have contributed to severe reactions in frail, elderly people. Pfizer and BioNTech are working with the Norwegian regulator to investigate the deaths.

news_headline: Google's 'Look to Speak' feature lets users pick phrases with eyes
news_article: Google's new accessibility feature, "Look to Speak", allows users to use their eyes to select phrases from a list and have them spoken aloud. Users can simply look left, right or up to navigate and select phrases from a customisable list. The feature uses a device's front-facing camera to detect where the user is looking.

news_headline: Facebook employees get 3 days off to 'take a break': Report
news_article: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has given three days off to his employees worldwide as a reward for working through "unprecedented challenges" this year, CNBC reported. "The idea here is to give as many people as possible a break," Zuckerberg wrote in an email. Facebook employees in the US have received the entire week of Thanksgiving off.

news_headline: India had largest reductions in malaria cases in SE Asia in 20 yrs: WHO
news_article: According to WHO's latest World Malaria Report, India made "impressive gains" with reductions of 18% and 20% in malaria cases and deaths respectively, over the last 2 years. India recorded the largest reductions in the cases in Southeast Asia from approximately 20 million to 5.6 million in 20 years from 2000-2019. Malaria cases reduced by 73% in the region.

news_headline: What is the 'balloon boy hoax', for which US parents were pardoned recently?
news_article: In 2009, Richard Heene and his wife Mayumi claimed their son had been carried away by a homemade helium balloon. It led to large-scale search operations as the balloon's flight was followed live by media. However, the boy was found in the attic of his home and authorities accused the parents of carrying out a hoax as a publicity stunt.

news_headline: Secret Service used porta-potty, Obama's toilet after being barred by Ivanka: Reports
news_article: US Secret Service has been paying $3,000/month since 2017 for an apartment near Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner's home in Washington to provide toilet facilities to agents protecting the couple, Washington Post reported. The report added Ivanka had barred them to use toilets at her home. Officials earlier resorted to a porta-potty, as well as bathroom of Barack Obama's home.

news_headline: Google to pay French publishers for news previews
news_article: Google on Thursday signed an agreement with a group of French publishers over copyrights under which the US tech giant will pay news outlets for content online. In a first for Europe, the principles agreed upon include criteria such as daily volume of publications, monthly internet traffic and "contribution to political and general information", the two said in a statement.

news_headline: Ex-Republican US President Bush to attend Biden's inauguration
news_article: Former Republican US President George W Bush will attend the inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris on January 20, his chief of staff said. Bush had also attended Barack Obama and Donald Trump's inaugurations. However, It's unclear if President Donald Trump, who is refusing to concede defeat in the presidential election, will attend the inauguration.

news_headline: WHO team to arrive in China on Thursday to probe origins of COVID-19
news_article: A group of experts from World Health Organization will be arriving on Thursday in China for an investigation into the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, China's National Health Commission said. WHO Director-General Tedros Ghebreyesus expressed disappointment last week over delays in necessary permissions, saying he had "made it clear" that the mission was a priority for the UN health agency.
